_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Executive Summary of the Griffith Energy Facility is as follows:

Process Description

Griffith Energy is a 520-megawatt natural gas fired combined cycle electric generating facility with the peaking capacity of up to 650 megawatts. 
 
The on site reportable substance regulated under the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR 68) is anhydrous ammonia. Anhydrous ammonia is utilized at the Griffith Energy facility in the chiller system. Approximately 143,000 pounds of liquid ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the system that enhances gas turbine performance and efficiency during warm weather conditions by cooling the turbine inlet air. The ammonia is contained in various vessels, piping, evaporators and compressors comprising the chiller system. All equipment used within the chiller system has been designed and constructed under codes and standards regulated by the ammonia refrigeration industry.

Chiller System Safety

Griffith Energy is in compliance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals and 40 CFR 68, CAA Section 112 EPA Risk Management Program.

In addition to the required OSHA, EPA and corporate safety programs that will be mandated within the facility, the following engineering and administrative controls will be in place to eliminate, or reduce the possibility of an accidental anhydrous ammonia release at the Griffith Energy facility:

?    Refrigeration Control System monitors and controls compressors, condenser, vessels and ammonia pumps. System displays continual operational status of equipment and controls alarms / shutdowns for out of parameter operation.
?    High level alarm and system shut offs are installed on pressure vessels. Abnormal operating levels sensed in the ammonia vessels will activate a shutdown of the chiller system compressors. 
?    Pressure relief valves are configured to all pressure vessels to eliminate the potential of an over-pressure condition within the vessels and the amm

onia chiller system.
?    Emergency stop button installed outside chiller building and in facility main control room to stop all ammonia refrigeration equipment in the event of a release.
?    Electronic ammonia detection installed in pressure safety relief vent stack. Detection system activates visual alarms at the facility main control center to alert personnel of a possible ammonia leak in the chiller system.
?    Preventative maintenance program are established within the maintenance department to ensure all ammonia system components are maintained in optimum operational and mechanical condition.
?    Continual vibration analysis of compressors and condenser fan drive shafts is provided to alert maintenance personnel of potential equipment malfunction, or failure.
?    Ammonia system operators receive system training from outside contractors with extensive knowledge and experience with anhydrous ammonia.
 
Worst Case Release Scenario

The worst case scenario depicts a catastrophic failure of the high pressure receiver that is located outside, adjacent to the evaporative condenser and chiller system covered area.
The high pressure receiver is capable of holding 115,000 pounds, however administrative controls limit the operating level of the receiver to 50% of the total capacity. 
The scenario amount that was used for modeling purposes was the 50% capacity, or 57,500 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. The resulting vapor cloud from the release produced a toxic endpoint of 6 miles from the Griffith Energy facility using the meteorological conditions specified by EPA. The endpoint was determined using atmospheric dispersion modeling via ALOHA, (Areal Locations Of Hazardous Atmospheres). In comparison, the EPA's RMP Comp was also used for modeling. RMP Comp yielded a more conservative 3.7 miles to the toxic endpoint. 

Alternate Case Release Scenario

The alternate case scenario involves an over pressure condition in the flash economizer. The overpressure condition results in a vapor rel

ease through the flash economizer's pressure relief valve. The resulting vapor release produces a vapor cloud that extends approximately 500 yards from the point of release at the releif valve vent stack.

Griffith Energy has had no accidents associated with ammonia use.

Emergency Response

Griffith Energy's emergency response plan is a detailed document, which discusses the role of employees and management in an emergency situation. Procedures have been developed for: 1) pre-emergency planning and coordination; 2) personnel roles and lines of authority; 3) training; 4) communication; 5) emergency recognition and prevention; 6) safe distances and places of refuge; 7) site security and control; 8) emergency alerting and response; 9) personal protective and emergency equipment; and 10) medical surveillance. All emergency response personnel undergo training and records of this training are maintained and updated on site.  The plan outlines specific procedures for evacuations, incident alarms and alerting.  Depending upon a given situation, the Kingman Fire Department would be called to provide assistance.
